awd_abstract_narration:
Dr. Takeshi Inomata and Dr. Daniela Triadan of the University of Arizona will examine the origins of Maya civilization between 1000 and 700 BC, focusing on the questions of 1) whether Maya civilization developed through local processes, under direct influence from Olmec civilization, or through complex interactions among various regions; and 2) whether formal ceremonial complexes emerged during the transition from mixed subsistence to fully-established maize agriculture. It has traditionally been argued that the Mayan civilization developed from a geographically 'Olmec' predecessor and is thus derived. Work by Inomata and Triadan in southern Mexico potentially challenges this hypothesis and suggests a more complicated narrative which includes not only potential inter-regional interaction but also an underlying shift in subsistence practices from part to full time agriculture. The question is important because complex societies developed at roughly the same time in many regions of the world and scientists wish to understand what factors underlie this process. The project directed by Dr. Inomata and Dr. Triadan will contribute to the cross-cultural understanding of how interregional interaction affects the process of political transformation.

The research team will examine multiple sites located in the Middle Usumacinta region of southern Mexico, located between the Maya lowlands and the Olmec heartland. The project research will include: 1) airborne laser survey (LiDAR); 2) the ground-truthing of LiDAR data through pedestrian surveys; and 3) excavations of the known sites and those located in the LiDAR survey to examine their chronology. The largest site in the region, Aguada F'nix, includes a rectangular platform, measuring 1.4 km in length. The study of those poorly-known monumental constructions dating between 1000 and 700 BC may transform our understanding of social processes leading to the development of Maya civilization.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences
org_div_long_name: Division of Behavioral and Cognitive Sciences

perf_inst.perf_str_addr: School of Anthropology, U of Ari

por.por_cntn:
We conducted archaeological investigations in southern Mexico to examine the initial development of Maya civilization. The site of Aguada Fenix that we identified features a large platform, which measures 1400 x 400 m horizontally and 10 to 15 m in height. This enormous site and related sites in the region presented the possibility to transform our understanding of early Maya and Mesoamerican societies. Our specific objectives included: 1) refining the chronologies of Aguada Fenix and related sites to examine the timing of the emergence of standardized complexes and the processes of their development; 2) examining the lifeways of the builders of these complexes, in particular, their level of mobility, subsistence, and the degree of social inequality; and 3) examining whether those standardized complexes were built simultaneously or at different times.

We conducted: 1) excavations in the central part of Aguada Fenix; 2) test excavations in other sites in the region; and 3) ground-truthing of lidar data in the region. At Aguada Fenix, we excavated the central area of the large platform found at Aguada Fenix. There is a formal complex called an E Group, and we excavated the plaza of this group. We also excavated the southern and northern parts of the Aguada Fenix platform. As to the test excavation program, we excavated multiple groups located around the major platform of Aguada Fenix. In addition, we excavated other sites in the region, including Buenavista, Rancho Zaragoza, La Carmelita, El Tiradero, and El Codo. For the ground-truthing of the lidar data, we conducted a pedestrian survey to verify features identified in lidar data. We conducted intensive surveys within Aguada Fenix and other areas, including the areas along the Usumacinta rivers.

In terms of the project results, through the analysis of lidar data that covered an area of 84,516 km2 in the Golf Coast region of Mexico, we identified 478 formal rectangular and square complexes, probably dating from 1,050 to 400 BC. We have refined the chronology of Aguada Fenix and related sites. Aguada Fenix was built between 1050 and 750 BC. Other sites, including La Carmelita, emerged around 900 BC and were abandoned around 750 BC. We uncovered a probable residential structure, which was a simple, low platform carved out of bedrock. This find is consistent with our assumption that most people did not build substantial residences because they were seasonally mobile. The isotope analysis of a human skeleton from Aguada Fenix indicates that this person was eating a considerable amount of maize, but the quantity of grinding stones from our excavation was small, and they were also consuming a significant amount of aquatic resources. These data suggest that they were in the transition from a mixed economy to more intensive maize agriculture.

The results of our investigations indicate radically different processes for the early Maya in the transitions to a sedentary lifestyle than previously thought. Monumental constructions seem to predate full sedentism and the full establishment of intensive agriculture. These processes are similar to ones observed in other parts of the world, such as Göbekli Tepe in Turkey, Caral in Peru, and Poverty Point in Louisiana. In addition, important cosmological ideas seem to have been shared over an extensive region along the Mexican Gulf coast, encompassing what we call the Olmec region. These new findings add to the growing corpus of evidence that is changing the narrative of the processes involved in the emergence of large settlements and monumental constructions.

We trained 2 US graduate students, 3 Mexican master students, and 2 Guatemalan master/doctoral students. We are also advising 2 Mexican master’s students at UNAM. We also collaborating with 2 Mexican postdoctoral scholars, and scientists from the US, Japan, France, and Germany.

 


Last Modified: 04/27/2023
Modified by: Takeshi Inomata
